Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Instrumentation for Spatially Relevant Plant Metabolomics and Proteomics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project uses funds to add an integrated mass spectrometry-based tissue imaging system, including a tissue sectioning station and a new generation MALDI-based quadrupole-time of flight mass spectrometry (Q-TOFMS) system that incorporates integrated ion mobility spectrometry, to the M.J. Murdock Metabolomics Laboratory (MML, http://www.murdockmetabolomics.wsu.edu, co-directed by three of the PIs) at Washington State University. Addition of this integrated instrumentation system to the MML enables researchers in the IBC and the WSU campus as a whole to acquire tissue imaging data that incorporates not only high mass accuracy and high resolution MS and MS/MS-based identification of proteins and metabolites, but also ion mobility spectrometric characterization of such compounds, increasing confidence in compound identification and quantification, while reducing noise in data acquisition. A critical missing link in past research has been the ability to identify, at the cellular or sub-tissue level, where biochemical processes occur or how pathways are regulated, especially in complex organs such as plant stems, roots, rhizomes and leaves. Acquisition of this integrated instrumentation enables fundamental mechanistic questions to be addressed that have remained unanswered for decades due to inadequate spatial resolution of previous analytical approaches. The integrated tissue imaging system will be housed in a newly renovated lab within the MML designed to accommodate such instrumentation, and expands the MML's current strengths in metabolomics and proteomics, furthering the goal of developing the MML as a world premier plant metabolomics facility.

Plants produce a fantastic diversity of compounds and substances that are used in pollination, plant defense, communication within individual plants and between plants and other organisms, among many other functions. Many of these highly specialized substances, such as flavors, fragrances, gums, resins, toxins, structural components, and nutritional and medicinal compounds, are produced in very few cell types or even in individual cells in plants. The ability to detect and measure various metabolites and the proteins that produce them in distinct single cell types in plant tissues has long been near impossible, even though this ability is vital in the long run to obtain a complete understanding of plant metabolism. It is generally considered that such knowledge is critical to future efforts to improve plants for human use. Regulation of these processes at the individual cellular level in plants is poorly understood, largely as a result of inability to detect and measure metabolites in specific plant cells. The new tissue imaging technology allows for detection and measurement of metabolites and proteins in specific cells in complex biological tissues such as stems, roots, rhizomes, flowers and leaves, and other specialized cell types in plants, or other tissues in other organisms (fungi, animals, insects, etc.). This new technology thus enables researchers to test hypotheses about important and fundamental biological processes related to medicinal plant metabolism, biofuel production, plant-insect interactions and basic plant biochemistry, among other areas. Data acquired with this instrument system will be part of the research projects of graduate students, undergraduate students and post-doctoral fellows in the fields of plant biochemistry, chemistry, interdisciplinary omics, and metabolic engineering. In addition, the new instrument system will be integrated into two specific efforts to attract current and future students to the fields of plant biochemistry and metabolomics particularly and to science in general and to provide educational advantages to the students at WSU. First, plant tissue imaging will be incorporated into the Advanced Plant Biochemistry course taught by CoPI Lange. Second, PI Gang will participate in CoPI Weller's "Pumping-Up the Math and Science Pipeline: Grade School to College" program that focuses on Native American and Hispanic populations on the Colville Reservation (largest in the Pacific Northwest) and in non-tribal regions surrounding Omak, WA, which hosts high school seniors for summer research internships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to fund the acquisition of a MALDI-MS-based tissue imaging system to add to the M.J. Murdock Metabolomics Laboratory capabilities at Washington State University, thus enabling for detection and measurement of metabolites and proteins in specific cells in complex biological tissues such as stems, roots, rhizomes and leaves, and other specialized cell types. This new technology thus enables researchers across the WSU campus to test hypotheses about important and fundamental biological processes in plants and other organisms (fungi, animals, insects) related to medicinal plant metabolism, biofuel production, and basic plant biochemistry, among other areas, including human health. The instrumentation has been utilized by a large number of researchers on the WSU campus and has been used to study important basic and applied science questions in a number of plant species. The focus of use of this MRI-funded instrumentation has been demonstration of the utility of the approach and the breadth of its applicability across plant science research. The research papers that are now being published by the users of this instrumentation are clearly demonstrating its broad utility. A core component of the impact that this project is having is particularly tied to development of methods that produce high quality, reproducible data from plant tissue sections. Overall, the results generated by use of this instrumentation clearly demonstrate that MALDI-based imaging can be a powerful tool in plant science research, particularly when localization or distribution of the molecules within the plant tissue is an important factor in understanding how the biological system functions.

A large number of graduate students and post-doctoral researchers on the WSU campus have been trained on how to implement this new technology into their research programs. This has opened up new avenues for research that were not previously possible to them, thereby increasing their competence, experience, and abilities. Over thirty scientific papers and several dozen seminars and conference talks have resulted from the use of this instrumentation. The Cougar Quest and Pipeline Summer Internship programs introduced this technology to high school students from Washington State at a formative point in their science education and have succeeded in encouraging participants to pursue degrees in science. Because this MRI-funded instrumentation was quickly shown to have a large impact on the research activities of numerous WSU scientists, a new core laboratory was established at WSU, the Tissue Imaging and Proteomics Lab, which greatly expands these capabilities by adding two complementary MALDI-MS Imaging systems.
